title: 104_hr1620
content: The Act may be cited as the "Brownfield Cleanup and Redevelopment Revolving Loan Fund Pilot Project Act of 1996". The Congress finds that contaminated and underused industrial sites in distressed communities face economic challenges in securing funding for cleanup and redevelopment. These sites, once cleaned up, can provide significant public benefits and promote environmentally sound practices. Voluntary cleanup programs encourage private sector involvement in remediation efforts. The Act aims to revitalize distressed communities by providing loans for cleanup of industrial properties to attract private investment, promote clean manufacturing, and create local jobs. States can use Federal funds to support cleanup and redevelopment projects through revolving loan funds. The Act establishes a pilot project for a revolving loan fund to support cleanups under state voluntary cleanup programs. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will establish a pilot project to provide capitalization loans to States for creating or expanding revolving loan funds for environmental cleanups. Loan applications must demonstrate State voluntary cleanup programs with public participation opportunities. The Environmental Protection Agency will establish a pilot project to provide capitalization loans to States for creating or expanding revolving loan funds for environmental cleanups. States must demonstrate voluntary cleanup programs with public participation opportunities, technical assistance, oversight for compliance with laws, and certification of cleanup completion. States must also show evidence of providing a matching share of at least 20 percent of cleanup costs and describe their revolving loan program capabilities. The Environmental Protection Agency will establish a pilot project to provide loans for voluntary cleanups under the State's program, prioritizing facilities for industrial reuse and job creation. Borrowers must demonstrate creditworthiness and cleanup ability. The Environmental Protection Agency will establish a pilot project to provide loans for voluntary cleanups under the State's program, prioritizing facilities for industrial reuse and job creation. Borrowers must demonstrate creditworthiness and cleanup ability. The State will begin repayment of the loan within 5 years, and the loan will not be used for new construction, environmental fines, or speculative assessments. Other elements may be included as deemed appropriate by the Administrator. The Administrator will determine the distribution of funds among eligible States for capitalization loans, not exceeding 15% of the available amount each year. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1996, and $7,500,000 for each of the fiscal years 1997 and 1998. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. An "eligible facility" under this Act is a property in a State with environmental contamination that hinders its use, development, or reuse, but excludes facilities eligible for abatement under another Act or currently under federal enforcement action. An "eligible facility" under this Act includes facilities on the National Priorities List, facilities requiring permits under the Solid Waste Disposal Act, and land disposal units with closure requirements specified in a closure plan or permit. Facilities subject to corrective action or high priority evaluation under the Solid Waste Disposal Act, facilities eligible for response assistance under the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund, and facilities owned or operated by the US government are considered eligible under this Act.
